Posted By: djflo (2/11/2011 11:34:42 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Absolutely amazing card. I used 4 in my Elf deck, Eldrazi deck, and pretty much any other deck that was green or splashed green. And even though I rarely used the kicker (unless I was going for a kill-shot), the ability to counter both opponent-based offensive and defensive spells in one instant is a ridiculous asset. And for the cost of ![Green](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=G&type=symbol) mana? This deserved uncommon, if not rare. But I'm glad Wizards made it widely accessible at *common* so that it's affordable not just to the rich.  
  
Art is pretty ferocious. While one could ask, "is he being *subdued* or *strengthened* by the vines?" you only need to know the function of the card to understand. I think more color and/or definition could have been used in the background, but it's fine as is. The perspective is very powerful and is sure to remind your opponent that being on the receiving end of the kicker for this spell is not something that is to soon be forgot.
posts.html:
Absolutely amazing card. I used 4 in my Elf deck, Eldrazi deck, and pretty much any other deck that was green or splashed green. And even though I rarely used the kicker (unless I was going for a kill-shot), the ability to counter both opponent-based offensive and defensive spells in one instant is a ridiculous asset. And for the cost of mana? This deserved uncommon, if not rare. But I'm glad Wizards made it widely accessible at common so that it's affordable not just to the rich.

Art is pretty ferocious. While one could ask, "is he being subdued or strengthened by the vines?" you only need to know the function of the card to understand. I think more color and/or definition could have been used in the background, but it's fine as is. The perspective is very powerful and is sure to remind your opponent that being on the receiving end of the kicker for this spell is not something that is to soon be forgot.
